Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project will develop the software and high school curricula to teach programming using mobile devices that will allow students to walk around and interact with each other as they develop programs for virtual robotics competitions. The project is driven by the hypothesis that a mobile, collaborative programming platform will improve learning outcomes in designing, generating, and evaluating algorithmic knowledge. The hypothesis has been subdivided into four measurable outcomes focusing on learning, transfer of programming knowledge, engagement, and procedures. Both learning and system development are addressed in the proposed research.

The broader significance and importance of this project, if successful, are to fundamentally change how students learn computer literacy. Rather than sitting at a computer to develop programs, students actively move around and interact in the task of preparing for robot competitions. This work may engage a more diverse group of students in learning the basics of programming, a key skill for the 21st century workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project are to develop and implement a mobile collaborative programming platform to focus on the design, generation, and evaluation of algorithmic knowledge, strategies, and models to determine pathways to stronger understanding of programming content as well as levels of increased motivation.  In general we seek to determine why and how building blocks of programming grow into deeper understanding.

In year 1, for the primary in-school enactment, 41 high school physics and robotics students were taught the IPRO programming environment, which is available from the App Store and can be used on any iPod or iPhone. In a larger enactment, 53 high school girls in a summer camp benefitted from IPRO training. In addition, the system was deployed into three after-school groups for disadvantaged youth: two in south San Antonio (n=16) and two in Austin, TX (n=12). In year 2, in-school enactment consisted of approximately 70 middle school students that were taught the IPRO environment. In a larger enactment, 57 high school girls in a summer camp benefitted from IPRO training.

In years 3-5 we analyzed the data to determine the types, or categories of programs that students created and whether there were patterns in the sequence of code block categories that early programmers use. We characterized how each student was programming by looking at the predominant types of commands (action, logic, sensor, or combinations) they were using at two and a half minute intervals. We then clustered the sequences of their use of command types over time. We also looked at how the students worked in teams as they were able to physically move around the room and communicate with other students as they programmed.

Our results from two years of study of girls in the IPRO programming environment provide insight into the learning process as it unfolds, the role of collaboration in learning during this process. Additionally, this study highlights an emerging type of learning, computational literacy, among an underrepresented group, high school girls. Our study showed:

 

1. Students started with a period of exploration during an initial period. This was evident by students transitioning to a new predominant block type approximately every two and a half minutes.

 

2. After the initial period, students changed to either working with one of four predominant block types (Action, Action-Logic-Sensor, Logic-Sensor, and Sensor) or cleared their boards and did not add new blocks, but still remained engaged in other ways.

 

3. The length of the initial period of exploration differed by cluster. Students in the “None” cluster had the longest initial period, while students in the “Logic-Sensor” cluster had the shortest initial period.

 

4. Most teams consisted of diverse types of programmers.

 

5. The programs of some teams were more advanced than the programs of others.

 

We had expected students to move toward a more complex form of programming (sensor and logic), but this did not occur. Instead they moved toward a type of programming different from their team members. We conclude that team membership played an important role in student programming development, which supported our hypothesis that collaboration would support programming. It is important to note that within only 90-minutes of programming in collaborative teams, students exhibited some attributes that would be expected of experienced programmers.
